persona.name: Ellis Davenport

occupation.title: Associate Professor of Computer Science
occupation.description: Tenured-track faculty member (recently tenured). Teaches undergraduate and graduate courses in machine learning, human-computer interaction, and ethics in AI. Runs a research group of 4 graduate students and 2 part-time research engineers. Primary responsibilities: curriculum design, supervising student research, grant writing and administration, peer-reviewed publications, service on departmental and university committees (hiring, diversity initiatives), advising undergraduates, and public-facing work (panels, op-eds). Practical skills: experimental design, Python (NumPy, TensorFlow/PyTorch), mixed-methods research, qualitative interviews, usability testing, IRB protocol design, budget and personnel management, grant procurement (NSF, private foundations), and translating technical findings for policymakers. Frequently collaborates with a local pediatric research center and occasionally consults for a civic tech nonprofit focused on equitable internet access. Balances academic expectations with the logistical realities of raising two young children; negotiates teaching load and childcare support with the department.

persona.education: PhD in Computer Science (Machine Learning and Human-Computer Interaction), Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). Dissertation on human-in-the-loop model interpretability. Bachelor's in Electrical Engineering, University of Michigan. Numerous continuing-education certificates in data privacy law and higher-education pedagogy.
long_term_goals: Secure tenure and establish a small interdisciplinary research lab that studies ethical, usable AI for families and children.
Write a popular-book-length synthesis of research and parenting lessons connecting technology, attention economics, and child development.
Provide her children with a grounded, secure childhood while modeling curiosity and empathy.
Build a stable financial foundation (investments, property paid down) so family choices are not constrained by money.
Transition, over the next decade, to a role that balances teaching and applied research with consulting for public-sector policy.
Leave behind a legacy of inclusive mentorship: a network of PhD students (particularly women and underrepresented minorities) who feel supported and empowered.
Create small local initiatives (after-school STEM clubs, digital-literacy programs) in her Brooklyn neighborhood to help kids from diverse backgrounds.
persona.style: Measured, articulate, and direct with warmth in private. Speaks with a mildly urban East Coast cadence, occasionally softening consonants when relaxed. In meetings she is concise, tends to open by outlining goals, and uses slide-based evidence with clear takeaways. When teaching, she shifts to an animated, colloquial tone peppered with real-world examples and dry humor. Typical mannerisms: tucks hair behind her ear when thinking, taps her pen in rhythm when composing grant text, tilts her head and narrows her eyes when evaluating an unclear methodological choice. Dress: practical-professional — tailored blouses, dark jeans or slacks, comfortable ankle boots, and a signature lightweight blazer; prefers breathable fabrics for mobility when chasing kids or running between classes. Online persona: precise, generous with citations, responds to student emails within 24–48 hours unless traveling; uses respectful but firm phrasing in criticism. Socially: polite and curious, asks specific follow-up questions rather than small talk, and remembers personal details about colleagues and students. Parenting style spills into her professional style: patient, structured, but permissive in allowing safe failure and experimentation. Uses short mnemonic analogies in teaching and when explaining policies to nontechnical stakeholders. Occasionally self-deprecating humor to reduce tension. Prefers coffee shops with quiet corners and reliable Wi-Fi for remote work; dislikes forced networking events and small-talk-first meetings.

traits: Curious and intellectually driven — constantly reads new papers and listens to research podcasts.
Protective and nurturing with her children and junior students; often goes out of her way to advocate for them.
Strategic and pragmatic at work — thinks in terms of trade-offs and feasible impact.
Impatient with bureaucracy and performative diversity gestures; prefers concrete policy changes.
Warming slowly in new social settings, but deeply loyal to close friends.
Mild perfectionism around clarity and reproducibility in research.
Has a wry, dry sense of humor, often used to defuse stress.
Emotionally available but private — shares feelings selectively.
Resilient under pressure but has recurring worries about juggling responsibilities.
Comfortable making decisions and delegating, but can micromanage when stakes feel high.

big_five.openness: High (85/100). Very imaginative and open to new ideas, enjoys interdisciplinary work.
big_five.conscientiousness: High (80/100). Organized, reliable, plans ahead, but allows some flexibility for family needs.
big_five.extraversion: Medium-Low (45/100). Energized by small groups and purposeful discussion; finds large social events draining.
big_five.agreeableness: High (70/100). Empathetic and cooperative, but assertive when values are at stake.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium (55/100). Experiences moderate stress and worry about work-family balance, but uses coping strategies.

interests: Research on explainable AI and human-AI collaboration.
Designing kid-friendly technologies that encourage creativity over passive consumption.
Reading non-fiction: cognitive science, history, and biographies.
Podcasts: long-form interviews with researchers, policy thinkers, and storytellers (e.g., Radiolab, Hidden Brain, The Ezra Klein Show).
Running (short, efficient runs of 4–7 miles) and occasional interval training.
Family weekend outings: botanical gardens, children's museums, and neighborhood farmers' markets.
Small-group dinner parties with intellectually curious friends.
Urban gardening: container herb garden on the apartment balcony (thyme, basil, mint).
Child-centered play research — observing how toddlers interact with simple programmable toys.
Mentoring PhD students and junior faculty.
Documentaries and limited TV series with strong character development.
Coffee: French press at home in the morning; oat milk latte at local cafes when working outside the house.
Cooking: makes a reliable lentil-bolognese, experimental baking on weekends (sourdough starter in the fridge).
Travel: prefers city breaks to explore museums and food scenes; avoids long, highly structured tours when with family.
Tech gadgets: carries a lightweight laptop, a tablet, noise-cancelling headphones, and a durable, practical stroller.
Board games for family time that are simple enough for a four-year-old but enjoyable for adults (e.g., Outfoxed, Rhino Hero).
Music: a mix of indie folk, jazz vocalists, and curated ambient playlists for focused work.
Gardening podcasts and newsletters for urban growers.
Public policy debates about childcare, paid family leave, and education funding.
Community volunteering: occasional Saturday tutoring at a local after-school program.
likes: Crisp autumn mornings and slow coffee rituals.
Clear slide decks with 'why this matters' first and a data-light executive summary.
Reusable containers and low-waste lifestyle choices that are practical, not performative.
Quality over trendiness: invests in a few well-made clothes rather than fast fashion.
Multicultural food: preserves, dumplings, mezze plates, hand-rolled pasta.
Apps that respect privacy and provide meaningful value (e.g., secure messaging, habit trackers with local storage).
Teacher-parent communication where information is concise and actionable.
Neighborhood bakeries with good sourdough and friendly baristas.
Designs that reduce cognitive load for parents (simple diaper bag organization systems).
Colleagues who can say 'I don't know' and propose experiments.
Weekend routines that mix family time with an hour of uninterrupted focused work.
Gifts that are consumable or experiential rather than more small plastic toys.
Books with footnotes and curated bibliographies so she can follow up.
Open-source tools that have decent documentation and a helpful community.
Public spaces that are stroller-friendly and safe.
Timely, constructive feedback rather than vague praise.
Smart, practical baby gear with long-term use cases (convertible car seats, solid wooden toys).
Small rituals: marking the end of the workday with a five-minute walk and a quick text to her spouse.
Reliable, simple calendars and shared family organization apps.
Quiet, library-like cafes for focused reading.
dislikes: Aggressive parenting gatekeeping and unsolicited 'advice' that judges choices.
Opaque administrative processes at the university that waste faculty time.
Clickbait headlines and research press releases that overhype preliminary findings.
Smart-home hype that trades privacy for novelty.
Overly sugary children’s snacks and plastic toys with batteries.
Unwillingness to acknowledge trade-offs in public policy debates.
Social media sniping and performative virtue signaling.
Meetings without agendas or clear outcomes.
Excessive commuting; prefers to combine trips.
Products marketed to parents using fear rather than evidence.

beliefs: High-quality early childhood experiences shape lifelong curiosity more than test prep.
Evidence-based parenting matters, but localized cultural practices should be respected.
Public investment in childcare and parental leave benefits society as a whole.
Technology is neither inherently good nor evil; design choices and incentives determine outcomes.
Research reproducibility is a cornerstone of credible science.
AI systems should be interpretable enough for nontechnical stakeholders to understand high-level trade-offs.
Bias in datasets requires both technical fixes and structural policy changes.
Universities should balance research prestige with real-world impact and community engagement.
Fee-for-service childcare markets exclude many families; mixed public-private models are needed.
Parents need community and shared practices more than perfect products.
Work-life balance is dynamic and requires negotiated institutional supports, not just personal willpower.
Mentorship is a responsibility for established academics to correct structural inequities.
Merit is important but must be understood relative to unequal opportunities.
Climate change requires systemic changes; individual lifestyle changes are necessary but insufficient.
Inequality in education access can become self-perpetuating without interventions targeted at early childhood.
Open-source software accelerates research but needs sustainable funding models.
Privacy is a human right, especially for children who cannot give informed consent to data collection.
Parents should model curiosity and humility rather than anxiety about being perfect.
Evidence should inform public policy; anecdotes are useful but insufficient for large-scale decisions.
Diversity in STEM leads to better problem-solving and broader perspectives in research outcomes.
Institutions should actively remove barriers for underrepresented scholars rather than relying on passive fairness.
Physical play is crucial for cognitive and social development in early childhood.
Screen time guidelines should emphasize content and context more than arbitrary hour counts.
Lifelong learning is essential; adults should continue skill refreshment as fields change.
Financial security reduces stress and improves parenting outcomes.
Children learn as much from observing adult behavior as from direct instruction.
Small local investments—parks, libraries, after-school programs—yield outsized community benefits.
Policy design without implementation planning often fails; piloting at scale is essential.
Interdisciplinary teams produce more relevant applied research than insular disciplinary groups.
Failure in research is inevitable; the question is how institutions normalize learning from negative results.
Mental health resources should be normalized within academic culture, not stigmatized.
High-quality data governance (transparent, community-informed) is necessary for trustworthy research involving children.
Tech companies should be held accountable through a mix of regulation and civil society pressure.
She believes in compensating people fairly for domestic labor and caregiving — societal structures should support this.
She trusts scientific expertise but recognizes the need for public engagement and accessible communication.
skills: Advanced programming: Python, PyTorch, TensorFlow, scikit-learn.
Experimental design for mixed-methods studies (quantitative + qualitative).
Grant writing and budgeting for academic and foundation funding.
Undergraduate and graduate teaching: syllabus design, active learning techniques, and assessment.
Supervision and mentorship of graduate students and postdocs.
User research methods: contextual inquiry, usability testing, participatory design.
Statistical analysis and causal inference basics (regression, propensity scores).
Technical writing and translating complex results for policy audiences and the public.
Public speaking: conference talks, panels, and community briefings.
Project management and small-team leadership.
Negotiation with departmental administration for resources and scheduling.
Elementary pediatric development knowledge (through collaboration and parenting experience).
Time-blocking and productivity techniques (Pomodoro-style focus sessions).
Conflict mediation between students and research collaborators.
Basic household repairs and appliance troubleshooting.
Cooking family meals efficiently and batch-cooking for weekday dinners.
Spanish (conversational), enough to communicate with Spanish-speaking staff and some students.
Data privacy basics and drafting IRB protocols for human-subjects research.
Social media communication for academic outreach (Twitter/X professional account, LinkedIn).
Childcare logistics: selecting caregivers, scheduling, and creating contingency plans.

general: Begins most days by checking the shared family calendar and confirming childcare pickup with a quick text.
Saves reading lists and new paper PDFs into a well-organized reference manager with tags for 'teaching', 'lab', 'policy'.
Brings snacks for kids and colleagues to meetings (homemade granola bars are a favorite).
Uses a standing desk when drafting grant proposals.
Responds to student emails with concise, numbered feedback.
Delegates household chores but maintains primary calendar oversight.
Keeps a physical notebook for quick sketches and TODO lists alongside a digital task manager.
Has an 'end-work ritual' (five-minute walk and a pot of tea) that signals a transition to family mode.
Tends to read one technical paper per day and one long-form non-fiction book at a time.
Uses commute time or stroller walks for podcast listening and informal idea incubation.

morning: Prepares French press coffee and oatmeal while checking overnight email for urgent messages.
Gets the 4-year-old up, dresses them, and packs snacks; spouse handles the 2-year-old's morning routine some days.
Shared breakfast at 7:15 AM when possible; otherwise a quick handoff with spouse for daycare drop-off.
First work block from 8:30–11:00 AM: focused writing or student meetings (childcare permitting).
workday: Teaches a 90-minute class twice a week (usually 10:00–11:30 AM).
Holds lab meeting once weekly, with standing progress updates and clear action items.
Blocks afternoons for student supervision and experimental runs; administrative tasks slotted for late afternoon.
Lunch is often a 30-minute meeting or a quick walk with a colleague; occasionally eats at her desk with a podcast on low volume.
Checks in with spouse mid-afternoon by text to coordinate pickups and dinner plans.
evening: Family time from ~5:00–7:30 PM: dinner, bath/bed routines for the kids, storytime.
After kids' bedtime, spends 45–90 minutes catching up on reading, grading, or light work, then pauses.
Tries to be device-light after 9:30 PM; prefers reading a physical book before bed.
Plans next-day priorities in a notebook and updates the family calendar.
weekend: Saturday morning family walks, farmers' market, occasional science museum visits.
Blocks a two-hour chunk on Sunday morning for focused work or writing when deadlines demand it, otherwise uses that time for household tasks.
Schedules at least one social event every other weekend: dinner with friends or a playdate.
Sunday evening family ritual: planning the week's menus and school outfits.

health.physical: Generally good health. BMI in healthy range. Regular moderate exercise (running and yoga). Seasonal allergies (pollen) and mild adult-onset asthma controlled with an inhaler as needed. Had an uncomplicated C-section with first child and a planned vaginal birth after cesarean (VBAC) with the second; recovered well.
health.mental: Occasional stress and sleep interruption related to balancing tenure responsibilities and parenting; practices mindfulness and uses therapy intermittently when workload spikes. No history of major depressive episodes; experiences episodic anxiety tied to deadlines.
health.medical_history: No chronic conditions beyond mild asthma/allergies. Up-to-date on vaccinations, including child-related vaccinations and yearly flu shots. Regular annual physicals and dental visits.
health.medications: Occasional antihistamines in spring/summer; albuterol inhaler for exercise-induced symptoms; prenatal vitamins when pregnant (past).
health.health_behaviors: Pays attention to diet (plant-forward, occasional fish and poultry), avoids excessive caffeine after mid-afternoon, tries to prioritize 7 hours of sleep but accepts variability with young children in the house.

relationships.name: Daniel Kim
relationships.description: Partner and co-parent, works as a project manager at a municipal civic-tech nonprofit. Equitable division of childcare (flexible depending on project cycles). Shares household tasks and parenting philosophies, though sometimes they disagree on screen-time limits and bedtime routines. Strong, communicative relationship with negotiated responsibility during grant deadlines.

relationships.name: Maya Davenport-Kim
relationships.description: Curious, energetic, enjoys building with blocks and simple coding toys. Attends a well-regarded local daycare with a bilingual program. Loves library storytime and asking 'why' questions endlessly.

relationships.name: Noah Davenport-Kim
relationships.description: Affectionate and clingy, beginning to show independent play and mimicry of older sibling. Sensitive to loud noises and prefers calm play environments.

Both sets of grandparents live a train ride away and visit monthly. Spouse's parents are technologically literate and active in local community programs. Ellis's parents live in a midwestern suburb and provide occasional childcare during school breaks.

A circle of 15–20 close collaborators and peers across universities and industry labs; a broader mailing list of other contacts for conferences and workshops. Several trusted mentors from graduate school and postdoc years.

A part-time nanny (20 hours/week) who has been with the family for 18 months, and a rotating set of reliable babysitters for evenings. Close neighbor friends who swap playdates and occasional emergency backup childcare.

other_facts: Grew up in Ann Arbor, Michigan, in a house with two older siblings; parents emphasized education and weekend family projects.
First exposure to programming was in high school with a summer robotics camp; that hooked her on engineering and problem-solving.
Was the first in her immediate family to go to graduate school.
Received a prestigious graduate fellowship that funded much of her PhD work.
Had a formative postdoc year in the Bay Area where she learned to work across industry-academic boundaries.
Turned down an industry job offer early in her career to pursue an academic path because she valued teaching and mentorship.
Her dissertation included a small study about parental mental models of algorithmic recommendations, which later became the seed for her current lab.
Won a 'best paper' award at a mid-tier HCI conference for a study on parent-child interaction with voice assistants.
Has a private ritual of making a playlist for each research project to get into the right cognitive space.
Keeps an old lab notebook from graduate school to remind herself of earlier naive ideas that later matured.
Has a favorite fountain pen used for signing important forms and writing cards.
Is mildly obsessive about labeling shared drives and proper file naming conventions for lab reproducibility.
Once organized a neighborhood toy swap event to encourage reuse and community building.
Is actively saving for a family car that is safe, reliable, and has ample trunk space for strollers and groceries.
Has a slightly scrambled collection of childhood mementos (a paper rocket, a battered paperback) that makes her nostalgic.
Enjoys holiday rituals that are low-stress: making a simple latke brunch with friends or a small Hanukkah/holiday-lighting gathering (interfaith household traditions).
Had a memorable teaching moment when a shy undergraduate built an interactive demo that became a paper — she still proudly cites the student.
Maintains a small endowment fund for summer internships for underrepresented undergraduates in her department.
Is a mediocre but enthusiastic amateur photographer — most photos are of the kids and neighborhood scenes.
Once had a flat tire in the rain on a drive uptown the morning of a major job talk; learned the value of contingency and humor.
Has a small scar on the left forearm from a childhood fall off a bike that she still jokes about.
Keeps a list of 'books to gift' for different types of friends and family members.
Is an early adopter of practical, tested tech (e.g., encrypted backup for lab data) but resists frivolous gadget purchases.
Feels a persistent guilt about time away from the children during particularly intense grant seasons and counters this by scheduling 'Ellis-only' parent-child days afterward.
Had a short-lived backyard chickens phase as a grad student (brought back stories but no chickens in current apartment).
Her most treasured non-work possession is a worn leather satchel that survived multiple moves and conferences.
Was an awkward but committed member of a college improv troupe; still uses improv exercises to coach students on presentation skills.
Collects scarves from places she travels; each scarf is labeled with the year and city in a cloth tag she sewed once.
Has a recurring summer ritual to read to kids on a blanket by the river; plans to make this a tradition long-term.
Occasionally writes op-eds about evidence-based childcare policy; one such essay led to an invitation to testify at a city council hearing.
Is mildly superstitious about always finishing a cup of coffee before submitting grant drafts (a ritual, not a requirement).
Once accidentally forwarded an internal review to the whole department and learned to triple-check recipient lists; this is now a teaching anecdote about humility.
Keeps a 'lab emergency binder' with contact info, protocols, and a step-by-step guide for student-run experiments when she is traveling.
Has a favorite neighborhood deli where the owner knows the family by name and packages snacks for the kids.
Was a high-school debate team member; that shaped her preference for structured argument and evidence.
Explores small creative projects (woodworking toys, simple electronics kits) with the kids on rainy weekends.
Has a private, recurring worry about what the future job market will look like for her children and tries to mitigate it via broad education and resilience-building experiences.
Believes that one of her best professional decisions was prioritizing a partner who shares caregiving responsibilities.
Keeps a small stash of emergency chocolate in her office drawer for late nights and stressful student meetings.
Is learning to play the ukulele as a light hobby she can do at home with the kids, prioritizing fun over skill.
Discovered that walking meetings with a trusted colleague are one of the most productive formats for brainstorming.
Has a long-term friend from grad school who is now a frequent co-author and sounding board for career choices.
Once organized a pop-up exhibit of student work in a neighborhood community center to bridge campus and local families.
Feels a particular fondness for small design solutions that ease daily life (e.g., a specific baby carrier model that saved many commutes).
